snippet.textDisplay: Because there was very little the SNES could do graphically, so video games had to be immersive in storytelling. They had to be catchy enough to stay in your mind long after you played them, but also interesting enough to actually pull you in in the first place.  And, for the price, they had to be of such quality that players would feel like they got the right bang for their buck. Hence, the wide use of immersive, story-driven RPGs that are still memorable to this day.
snippet.textOriginal: Because there was very little the SNES could do graphically, so video games had to be immersive in storytelling. They had to be catchy enough to stay in your mind long after you played them, but also interesting enough to actually pull you in in the first place.  And, for the price, they had to be of such quality that players would feel like they got the right bang for their buck. Hence, the wide use of immersive, story-driven RPGs that are still memorable to this day.

snippet.textDisplay: Because if Snes shitty processor (it's fact!),and a powerful sound chip,developers had no choice but to make RPGs. Not all developers could program shmups and action games for it, because the action slows down to the Snes' inability to handle too many sprites on screen. Look at Gradius 3 and Castlevania 4.RPGs didn't require developers to show large number of sprites on screen. They were confined to RPGS for most of the time. For the record Snes processor was 3.58 mhz and Genesis was  7.67 mhz.
snippet.textOriginal: Because if Snes shitty processor (it's fact!),and a powerful sound chip,developers had no choice but to make RPGs. Not all developers could program shmups and action games for it, because the action slows down to the Snes' inability to handle too many sprites on screen. Look at Gradius 3 and Castlevania 4.RPGs didn't require developers to show large number of sprites on screen. They were confined to RPGS for most of the time. For the record Snes processor was 3.58 mhz and Genesis was  7.67 mhz.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Arc13

1. SNES had limited graphical capability, so they were able to focus more on story. Making RPG was the best excuse for a developer to craft a big, old, open-ended medieval story out of it.

2. The battle systems were easy to craft, since it's a text-based adventure with fancy sprites. Hardware-demanding real-time processes found in adventure and fps games were of little worry for this genre.

3. Final Fantasy for the NES/MSX motivated competition, and SNES was the chanced battleground.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Arc13

1. SNES had limited graphical capability, so they were able to focus more on story. Making RPG was the best excuse for a developer to craft a big, old, open-ended medieval story out of it.

2. The battle systems were easy to craft, since it's a text-based adventure with fancy sprites. Hardware-demanding real-time processes found in adventure and fps games were of little worry for this genre.

3. Final Fantasy for the NES/MSX motivated competition, and SNES was the chanced battleground.

snippet.textDisplay:
Not a lot to add here, but more recently, Square's The Last Remnant had some of this vibe going on -- an 8.2-8.3 quality mid-budget game with some interesting mechanics, plus up-tempo music that actually wouldn't be out of place in a top tier offering.  

Hmm, I still have my Lufia II cart, too...I wonder if it still has my save with a complete Iris Set?
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Definitely one of my favourite boss tracks of all times... :3

I miss Lufia II now.  The puzzles in the game were, when I originally played it (at about 11) probably the hardest puzzles I'd ever encountered in a game, and back then I didn't really have a walkthrough; just digging through old Nintendo Powers and praying the answer was in one of their help sections XD
snippet.textOriginal:
Definitely one of my favourite boss tracks of all times... :3

I miss Lufia II now.  The puzzles in the game were, when I originally played it (at about 11) probably the hardest puzzles I'd ever encountered in a game, and back then I didn't really have a walkthrough; just digging through old Nintendo Powers and praying the answer was in one of their help sections XD

snippet.textDisplay:
It's not really underrated. It is rated pretty highly across the internet actually.

But you're right, they don't make 'em like they used to. Lufia II is one of the best RPGs ever made, with awesome music, wonderful puzzles/dungeons, awesome characters and a great story.
snippet.textOriginal:
It's not really underrated. It is rated pretty highly across the internet actually.

But you're right, they don't make 'em like they used to. Lufia II is one of the best RPGs ever made, with awesome music, wonderful puzzles/dungeons, awesome characters and a great story.

snippet.textDisplay:
My brother bought the SNES with this game together(one package) back in '92. This game never got the respect that it deserved imo. This one actually set the tone a bit with really hard puzzles(Mountain of No Return, Worlds most Difficult Trick*cough*). Even if people can do these easily now, when I was only 7; it took FOREVER to complete this game. It was that hard.

Still, amazing for its time.
snippet.textOriginal:
My brother bought the SNES with this game together(one package) back in '92. This game never got the respect that it deserved imo. This one actually set the tone a bit with really hard puzzles(Mountain of No Return, Worlds most Difficult Trick*cough*). Even if people can do these easily now, when I was only 7; it took FOREVER to complete this game. It was that hard.

Still, amazing for its time.

snippet.textDisplay:
Back in the days, this was the shit.
Other RPG's didn't have a tune this rocking by then. (if you compare to how awesome it is to other super nintendo rpg's)

It really got you into the hype that "FINALY A BOSS FIGHT! :D" Was coming instead of some boring dark music... it rocks out your ears and makes you just want to play it over and over <333
